text:
```mydict = Dict('a'=>1,'b'=>1)
mydict['a'] 
mydict = Dict(:a=>1,:b=>"v")
mydict[:a]```
I understand that I am using symbol to access the value in the 2nd approach. But I am wondering what are the fundamental difference between these two approaches? When should I chose one over another. Thanks!

elements.text:
mydict = Dict('a'=>1,'b'=>1)
mydict['a'] 
mydict = Dict(:a=>1,:b=>"v")
mydict[:a]

I understand that I am using symbol to access the value in the 2nd approach. But I am wondering what are the fundamental difference between these two approaches? When should I chose one over another. Thanks!

attachments.title: When should a function accept a symbol as an argument?
attachments.text: Here is a summary of this thread that answers the original question “When should I write functions that accept symbols instead of strings or booleans?” If the function actually uses a symbol in a way that it cannot use a string, for example, appearing in a type parameter, then use a symbol. Thanks @Evey If the function uses the argument to choose one of a handful of behaviors, then either strings or symbols are acceptable. Consider the following when choosing: Symbols effectively need to be ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: When should a function accept a symbol as an argument?

text: in my opinion, the biggest differences are that you can write functions which use symbols as a type parameter using `Val(:somesymbol)` but not strings, and strings can be used for many common operations like writing to disk, but symbols cannot. of course, you can convert between them
